data.title: Mutiny in Heaven: The Birthday Party (2023)
data.meta_description: The thrilling, debauched and frequently hilarious adventures of the legendary Melbourne post-punk band, in their own words.
data.text:
Another one of those ”radical bands who get conventional documentaries” sorts of thing. It's not a bad film: there’s some decent montages and the live footage is great, even though most of it is easily available on YouTube. For anyone who likes the music of The Birthday Party, this will be enjoyable. However, part of what made Todd Haynes’ film about The Velvet Underground so good was that it through creative editing and use of image and sound managed to capture the magic of the band. I had hoped that film would set a new standard for these documentaries. I mean, is it too much to ask that a film about The Birthday Party should feel like an assault on…

Because I've never seen a recording of any of their live shows, I was concerned that not enough footage of the Birthday Party exists to make this the documentary about them that I wanted. I needn't have worried; the story of their short but explosive existence is illustrated with plenty of concert footage, as well as a couple of nightmarish music videos that they made.

Starting out in Melbourne as the Boys Next Door, Nick Cave and four schoolfriends soon relocated to London to find their place, and their sound, in the local post-punk scene. After a few intense months of doing various drugs instead, they began to get noticed, they recorded their debut album, and played packed gigs back…
